qa_pairs.S: Picardo was born in Jerez de la Frontera, in the Province of Cádiz in Andalucía, Spain on 18 June 1919. With his mother and his brothers he moved to Madrid, Spain.
qa_pairs.Q: Where was José Luis Picardo born and raised?
qa_pairs.A: He was born in Jerez de la Frontera, in the Province of Cádiz in Andalucía, Spain. He later moved to Madrid with his family.

qa_pairs.S: On 3 February 1997, at the age of 78, Picardo was elected Academician of the Real Academia de Bellas Artes de San Fernando (Royal Academy of Fine Arts of San Fernando), being proposed by Julio Cano Lasso [es], Fernando Chueca Goitia and Luis García-Ochoa Ibáñez [es].
qa_pairs.Q: Did José Luis Picardo receive any awards or recognition for his work?

qa_pairs.S: Particularly noted in his post-student days were illustrations portraying Madrid in the 1950s and 1960s, the Spanish protectorate in Morocco, and sketches of the Canarias (Canary Islands) in 1953.
qa_pairs.Q: What were some of the subjects that Picardo illustrated in his post-student days?
qa_pairs.A: Madrid in the 1950s and 1960s, the Spanish protectorate in Morocco, and sketches of the Canarias (Canary Islands) in 1953.

qa_pairs.S: On qualifying in 1951,[6][7] Picardo pursued his interest in historical architecture by collaborating on a number of building preservation and restoration projects with the Spanish architect and architectural historian Fernando Chueca Goitia [es], who was 8 years his senior.
qa_pairs.Q: Who did Picardo collaborate with for building preservation and restoration projects?
qa_pairs.A: He collaborated with Spanish architect and architectural historian Fernando Chueca Goitia.

qa_pairs.S: In 1951 in company with his fellow architect Carlos de Miguel he designed a centre for the Cofradía de Pescadores (Fishermen's Brotherhood) of Altea in the province of Alicante which attracted much attention but remained unbuilt.
qa_pairs.Q: What was one of the uncommissioned buildings that Picardo designed in the 1950s?
qa_pairs.A: He designed a centre for the Cofradía de Pescadores (Fishermen's Brotherhood) of Altea.

qa_pairs.S: With much imagination he personalised the characters he portrayed, for instance rendering the King of Hearts as the Emperor Charlemagne, the King of Clubs as Goliath, the King of Diamonds as Julius Caesar and the King of Clubs as Alexander the Great.
qa_pairs.Q: How did Picardo personalize the characters in the playing cards he designed for Loewe?
qa_pairs.A: Picardo personalized the characters in the playing cards by portraying the King of Hearts as the Emperor Charlemagne, the King of Clubs as Goliath, the King of Diamonds as Julius Caesar, and the King of Spades as Alexander the Great.

qa_pairs.S: Picardo set the main hospitality section of the Parador within the Colegio de Infantes, adding to the external south side of the cloister to provide a dining room and, above it, terraces for guest rooms facing the garden.
qa_pairs.Q: Where did Picardo locate the main hospitality section of the Parador?

qa_pairs.S: To the left of the entry, in the original guardhouse, he placed the reception area and to the right, where the old stables were situated, he placed the bar and cafetería, adding one single window to each space to allow in some daylight.
qa_pairs.Q: What did he place to the left and right of the entry?
qa_pairs.A: He placed the reception area to the left and the bar and cafetería to the right.

qa_pairs.S: In planning the interior decoration Picardo determined that the ground floor would be medieval in design in keeping with the original military use of the palace, and the upper floors would be more palatial in decor.
qa_pairs.Q: How did Picardo plan the interior decoration?
qa_pairs.A: He planned for the ground floor to be medieval in design and the upper floors to be more palatial.

qa_pairs.S: In 1964 Picardo was involved, with the Ministry of Information and Tourism, in investigating old buildings for conversion into a new Parador in the Province of Guadalajara.
qa_pairs.Q: What was Picardo's involvement in the investigation of old buildings?
qa_pairs.A: Investigating old buildings for conversion into a new Parador.

qa_pairs.S: Picardo had no qualms about his film set concept of restoration, using modern construction techniques and concealing them with traditional materials, as long as the buildings looked old rather than modern.
qa_pairs.Q: What was Picardo's approach to restoration?
qa_pairs.A: Picardo used modern construction techniques but concealed them with traditional materials to make the buildings look old.
